advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Intellivision video games. Realism goes past fiction"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably one of the first adverts for the Osborne 1.<br> Personal Computing, February 1982.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As NEC american office wanted the APC to compete with the IBM PC. So they tried to do a pastiche of the <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/photos.asp?t=2&c=274">Charly Chaplin IBM advert</a>.<br> It was not a good idea.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here are the 20 questions :-)<br><font color="#666666"> If you're looking for your first home computer, may we make a suggestion.<br> Tear out this page.<br> And ask these questions of every computer you look at.<br> 1) Is the basic price reason­able, say under £180?<br> 2) Does it work with a monitor as well as with an ordinary UHF TV?<br> 3) Does it include a basic training manual that doesn't require a science degree to understand?<br> 4) Does it have colour?<br> 5) And sound?<br> 6) Does it take cassettes?<br> 7) And cartridges?<br> 8) And can you operate them with joysticks working directly off the basic unit?<br> 9) Does it have a profes­sional quality keyboard that's guaranteed for twenty million de­pressions (and no headaches)?<br> 10) Does it have colour graphics that are capable of producing detailed pictures?<br> 11) Is the case robust enough to stand up to the kids?<br> ­12) Does it use a standard language that's not a million, miles away from English?<br> 13) Is there an expanding range of high quality sofrware available from the makers?<br> 14) Does the software in­clude educational programs for adults as well as the very young?<br> 15) And is there sofrware sophisticated enough to satisfy the experts?<br> 16) Does it use the most up to date technology, for instance the 6809E microprocessor?<br> 17) Will it drive a standard printer directly from the basic unit?<br> 18) Is it made in the UK?<br> 19) And for the basic price will I get an easily accessible, yet large memory of at least 32K?<br> 20) Or willI have to add lots of extras (and lots of money for that much?<br> After you've finished pester­ing every computer salesman in sight, compare your answers to these, Courtesy of the Dragon 32 (this is,after all, an ad for the Dragon)<br> Questions 1-19. Yes,yes,yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes and yes.<br> Question 20. No.<br> If you're thinking that that's a lot of computer for the money. you'd be right.<br> However, when you come to read the handbook you'll soon realise that somethings missing. The jargon usually asso­ciated with computers.<br> You see every part of the Dragon has been carefully designed to be easily under­stood,even by total beginners. Yet it has all the features an expert could want Just ask it. </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUASAR AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8 KB quasar system with the 4 color plotter/printer interface.<br><br> The small picture shows a complete system with memory expansion, modem and video interfaces.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT APR. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>John V. Blankenbaker designed the Kenbak-1 and marketed in the pages of Scientific American in 1971. The machine's name was taken from the middle of John's last name.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.vintage-computer.com" target="_blank">www.vintage-computer.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #9</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Teleplay advert for the Teleng Colourstars<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.geocities.com/doubledragon0uk//Home.html" target="_blank">Double Dragon Retro Mess</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #15</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £149 IN JUNE 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Your personnal computer for 670 F"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 68 years old, taunt Rose discovered that she was an exceptionally gifted child"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE FIRST M20 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>This Olivetti ancestor, also called M20, was born in 1920...<br> To note the superb design all the young italian secretaries were in love of! <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Karl-Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ONTEL ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks also to <b>Bob Hanrahan</b> for these pictures</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.colors: 16 among 64 in EGA mode, monochrom in Hercules mode
computer.description:
Just after the Atari ST series, Atari decided to launch a series of PC compatible systems. The PC-1 was the first model. It used the shell of the Atari Mega ST4 and its mouse. It held 512 KB of RAM, an optional 20 or 23 MB HDD, but didn't have ISA extension slot, to use a PC card, an expansion box was necessary. However, the PC-1 had Parallel, serial and mouse ports built-in as well as an universal video interface allowing either colour CGA and EGA or Hercules monochrome monitors to be connected to the same video port.
The range of Atari PC compatible systems was also comprised of: ? The PC3, a 8088 8Mhz based system with 640 KB ram, CGA graphics and 20MB hard drive, ? The PC4, a 80286 16Mhz based system with a 60MB hard drive in which - optionally- a 3.5 1.44 Mb drive could be fitted (the front needed to be cut out and the metal casing sawed by the user). It also featured VGA graphics, ? The ABC, a 80386sx 16Mhz model with a 40MB hard disk and vga graphics. This one came with a 3.5 floppy built in, ? The PC5, a 20MHz 80386 PC featuring 60 MB hard disk and SVGA graphics with same 3.5 floppy disk option as with the PC4, ? the N386 laptop. _______________________
computer.graphics: All CGA, EGA and Hercules resolutions
computer.name: PC

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PC1 - FRONT & REAR SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Rear connectors, from left to right:<br> • Mouse<br> • Parallel port<br> • Serial port<br> • Video output<br> • Video select switches<br> • External FDD unit<br> • Keyboard </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC1 - INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>There is no way to add an expansion card or another mass storage device into the case although one finds some unused expansion conectors on the main board (more info needed). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC1 - ORIGINAL DISKETTES</strong></font><br><blockquote>The PC-1 shipped with both MS-DOS and GEM OSs.</blockquote>
